This was the most expensive room of the trip and the smallest. the rooms are soooooo small. there are no fridge/coffee making facilities. there is hardly any place to walk around. however if you are looking fr cheap place to put your head down then this should be fine.the staff were very unfriendly and unhelpful. when i arrived my luggage had been misplaced by the airline. i informed the staff of this and advised when the luggage was expected to be delivered. way after the time passed i went down to ask if it the luggage had been received assuming it had not. to my surprise they said yes. they had not bothered to bring it up or let alone call me to inform me. i only had my hand luggage which did not include a change of clothes. in addition my luggage was just sitting there in the open at the reception and not even in a closed room...oh well.anytime i alsed for simple things like restaurant recommendation or directions it seemed like i was bothering the staff so i stoppedi will not be back not matter how cheap it was!
user_name:
Phoebe H
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Like everyone says, the location is great. I love the Upper West Side. And also the rooms are tiny -- the smallest I have ever seen. But they are sufficient and they are clean which is okay with me. However, the bed was seriously old school. Only a double with a cheap mattress and bad pillows. Also the cover was one of this polyester nylon covers that I hate. You can only imagine how infrequently they get washed and what people do on them! If they had a decent bed with good pillows and a duvet that gets washed after each use I would be okay with the size of the rooms as you aren't really in the room for very long. Also the room was very hot and it was only early May. We tried to increase the air flow and turn down the temperature but it was till a struggle. The room was very quiet however -- no noise from the street which was great.

Yes the room is small, but it is clean and centrally located....subway one block away, Central Park close by and lots of restaurants in the area. Staff is friendly and helpful. I would suggest bringing earplugs as the walls are thin, and there is a hum in the room. No street noise though. Given the prices of hotels in New York this was good value.

Stayed here for six nights during April 2013, and would stay again. Starbucks around the corner on Broadway. Restaurants, Supermarket and Market stores all nearby on Broadway. A great find for breakfast was City Diner, on the corner of 90th Street and Broadway, full of local New Yorkers.

The location is great: walking distance to many places such as Times Square, the Met, Morningside Heights. It was clean but laughably small. If you are a big person you won't be able to close the bathroom door. Luckily, neither of us is but we do have normal hearing. At 4 a.m. our first morning there, I could hear first a lengthy, loud call home, including a report on the small hotel room on the other side of our headboard. After the call home a lengthy, loud series of moans and thumping noises made me feel like I was in the room next door. Don't stay here unless you are thin and very hard of hearing.

We picked this hotel for the last 2 nights of our stay in New York. This was after staying at a Doubletree and a Marriott so maybe we just set the bar too high, but I don't think so. The rooms are even small by European standards and that's comparing it to a pension not a name brand room. There is really only room for carry on bags, but nothing larger. If you have a larger bag you would need to keep it closed and only open it when you need to get something out. The T.V. on the wall at the foot of the bed does need to be dodged when you try to get to the bathroom. Oh the bathroom--not one shelf or space for any of your toiletries! The rooms, however, are kept very clean and in good repair. The bedding is pathetic, old, and they do have something they call pillows. As there is no carpeting in the hotel it can be very noisy, so if you have sleep issues you should really reconsider.The location however is really nice. It is very close to so many good restaurants. The one I remember is Bodrum's--very good, but many others to pick from. Also not far from a Metro stop. The customer service is almost non-existent. They really have a way of making you feel that you are a bother. With all this being said if you have a tight budget then this would be an option for you.

I had read reviews and seen some photos before I booked a room at the Belnord. I knew the room was going to be small. Yet, when we checked in and opened the door to our room, I was still somehow amazed at HOW small it really was.It was clean and nice, though. But, even the hallways are tiny. The bathroom was also tiny, I soaked my feet every night after a long day of exploring the city and found that my 5'2 frame could n't even stretch out in the tub. Rooms in NYC during the time we were looking were about $200-$300/night on average and I got this one for about $165/night. The Upper West Side is a really nice neighbourhood and I even met Emma Stone at the Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf on the corner while I was there!The hotel staff was friendly enough, but the phones in the room don't dial out locally and there's no phone they'll let you use, either. The bed was comfy although the comforter was a little outdated. I would stay here again for a budget trip to NYC where I plan to spend as little time in the room as possible.

Stayed 4/3/13 - 4/5/13. The previous reviews were very helpful. Loved that (Subway 1) is soo close to the hotel. Everyone was very helpful. The hotel room was very clean and updated. Grocery stores, Central Park, American Museum of Natural History were all very close to the hotel. Do not hesitate, book now!

I love this hotel, the location is excellent. Close to train station close to Central Park and close to great restaurants.Always a favorite in NYC if you are on a budget and looking for a quiet location in the big apple.

Belnord is one of the worst places ever. yes, it's cheap -- but any smaller, and it'd be $100 per square foot! Couldn't even sit straight up in the commode. Couldn't shave and close the bathroom door at the same time. And the puny size was only the start. When we arrived, the room key wouldn't work the door -- sounds like a minor problem, but after four trips from the fifth floor down to the front desk oer a half hour, they still couldn't fix it, and had no other rooms to give us. So we spent our first night in the room only by virtue of a house key -- if we'd gone out, no way to get back in. They refused to change the room, and were not even sympathetic to our plight -- acted as though it happens all the time. Loud TV on most of the night, and the walls too thin to muffle the sound.

Yes, the rooms are small, very small - in fact the bed pretty much takes up the entire room. However, for these prices ($80/night), it's a steal in NY city. The room and bathroom are very clean, and most rooms are newly renovated and all are non-smoking. I had enough space to put my suitcase on a suitcase stool and to hang my clothes on the open clothes rack in the room. Yes, the view will likely be of a brick wall, however, it's a great hotel if you just need a clean, comfortable place to sleep. Ask for a room that doesn't face the street and it will be quiet. The wifi connection worked fine. The location is excellent - just a block away from the subway and a 10 minute walk to Central park. There are tons of restaurants nearby, including a Starbucks next door. The neighbourhood is quite safe, even at night. There is a printer on the main floor, that you can use, for a fee. The only downside are the front desk staff, who are not exactly the friendliest people in the world. I've stayed at this hotel 3 times (Jan / Feb 2013 & 2 yrs ago) and I would definitely recommend it for a short stay in NY.

The room is like a grave. If is so small that the bad takes 99% of the room. You can only come in withyourself without your begs because there is no roon for it. The floor and the bad shake when the air condition is on. There is no reply when you try to reach room service. Vary bad experience. Would not come again. Would rather sleep in the streets.

Belnord is a great value hotel for Manhattan due to its location and reasonable prices. If you are just looking for a clean room in a good location, I don't think this could go any better than Belnord. Because it's really close to Broadway Ave, it is not very quiet in the mornings, but this is what you should expect from this location. I haven't used its restaurant, and haven't spent much time in the room, but overall I liked the room I stayed for sleeping and resting. I was single but it would be comfortable enough room for couples. All in all, I wouldn't hesitate to stay there again if I were to stay in Manhattan.

I stayed four nights at the Hotel Belnord. The location is fantastic - Upper West Side, close to the park in a very safe and friendly neighborhood. The room was tiny, but very clean. Staff was friendly. The downside was the complete lack of soundproofing between the rooms and the hallway. If you're a light sleeper, bring ear plugs. No other amenities - I lost my toothpaste and they told me to go to CVS to buy more... However, it's a very good value and I would stay there again. Cleanliness and location combined with price can't be beat.

My husband and I stayed here November 2012 and LOVED it! The rooms was small but it is Manhattan so you expect that, The bathroom was bigger than the room which we found very funny. The location was great and close to the subway and shops. The price has gone up since we visited but we will still go there. The entire hotel was clean and the front desk was very helpful.

I stayed in this hotel twice, first in October 2012 and more recently in March 12-16 2013. It is a decent and safe place to stay. Great location, only one block to the subway and bus stops. Major Upper West Side attractions (such as the Museum of Natural History, Lincoln Center, etc.) within walking distance. Lots of stores and restaurants around. The rooms are very small. Basically, they would fit a full size bed and your bags. But they are clean. It can get a bit loud at night but that's mostly inconsiderate guests. The heating system is also very loud, I don't know if they can do anything about it. I had some internet connection problems during my first stay but it worked perfectly the second time. Ideal for people who travel alone. Might be a bit trying for couples. Good value for the price. Decent staff.

If you are looking for a comfortable bed and a great location, look no further. Belnord is located a short walk from the Central Park and subway station. The room itself was very small but clean. Wifi in the room works OK. Staff were friendly. If you are a budget traveler this is one of your best options in New York. I would stay there again

I received unauthorized charges on my card. I did not stay at this site. The staff was very rude and unprofessional. The place is substandard. You can find ideal lodging at a Hampton for close to the same price. They have a history of bug infestation. Pray before you stay.

If you just want a bed and bathroom to crash after a day of sightseeing then this is perfect. The location could not be better, it is a 5min walk from central park and the main museums. It is right next to Broadway, which is full of great places to eat, to get a taxi and with a near by subway entrance. It is roughly 10-15 dollars into midtown manhatten from the hotel, but your just outside of the madness enough to relax, but in a nice neighbourhood and within mintues from all major attractions.However the staff on the main desk are miserable, unresponsive and unhelpful. The rooms are totally basic but clean and comfortable. They are noisy though and small though. But would say its value for money and does the job. And the location is its biggest selling point

I recently stayed for a few days in this hotel. I found it adequate for the money charged which was very affordable. The room though small was very clean. The maids are very efficient. The Wifi needs to be improved upon. Would give it 70 out of a 100. Would definitely stay there again.

Not a bad hotel if you plan on staying in the city just a few nights. The rooms are pretty small though so any prolonged stay in this hotel may leave you feeling pretty cramped. With that said, the rooms are very clean and are cleaned daily. I would have given this hotel four stars if it wasn't for the poor wifi signal throughout the hotel. The wifi signal is very weak and is hit or miss. I was lucky if I stood connected to the internet for five minutes before the signal was lost and took me another 20 minutes just to try to connect again. I wasn't the only guest with this problem, I heard another man in the lobby complaining at the front desk about the wifi problem. Overall this is a great hotel, but if you need the interent to work/study you might want to find another place.
user_name:
Ron316
New York City, New York

review_body: They gave us the key to an occupied room and we walked in on a man in his underwear. When we went downstairs, there was another couple at the desk and they asked us, "Did you get someone else's room key too?" The desk clerks were laughing about it, but it wasn't funny to the man in his underwear. We were scared to leave anything in our room because they were just handing out room keys downstairs.Also, the rooms are the size of a bathroom.
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Meg M
New York, New York, United States

review_body: The good: +very inexpensive for NYC+newly renovated (was an apt until recently) including stone surfaces in the bathroom+upper westside location a bit calmer than midtown/Times Square - this is mainly a residential neighborhood but with many local restaurants, stores etc+clean+convenient to bus & subway including the bus lines that cross Central ParkThe bad:+very compact - we had a room with double bed (not queen or king), one nightstand, wall-mounted tv and no "extra" space - we did not mind (especially for the price), but you should know before booking+there is a tub in the bathroom but it is small, maybe 4' length (vs 5' for household standard)+most tourist sites are a bus/subway/taxi ride away (not a walk)+rates are capacity controlled; we paid under $100 for our room, when we asked the front desk if that was typical they said during a busy time our room could be $155 - which is *still* very inexpensive for NYC but is a big % more than we paid on a Tuesday

The hotel is a very simple, but quite cosy structure. The rooms are small, but they have parquet on the floor and the bathroom is newly renovated with everything you need inside. All the rooms are cleaned daily, they even change your towels and sheets. The wifi is working in all the room, but you have to ask for a new password everyday. The location is very good to reach almost all the city. The red metro is just crossing the main road. Stuff is kind. There's no possibility to have breakfast inside. Anyway starbucks, supermarkets and other places are very close.

I was really insistent about the area we stayed in as safaety was a priority and I was really pleased with this choice. Although the room was small and the bed was smaller than ours back home it was really cozy and the service was very good. Front desk even called my shuttle service for me to confirm the reservation and made no charge for the call, they stored our luggage away safely whilst we enjoyed our last day after checkout as we had an evening flight. The area was absolutely spot on, two blocks from central park, one block from the subway and 3 major roads all within walking distance that housed many fine eateries and bars and shops. The price we paid was cheap as chips however since it was off season I expected we'd get a good deal. A great first time location, would consider again. Only one downside, no coffee facilities in the room.

I have stayed at many hotels and this one is run by some hard nosed people who lie. This is not the best area to stay in but it was within 8 blocks of where I was going so I booked as I was visiting 8 blocks away. Primarily for the prices. They denied me a credit after they said on the phone I could cancel. Major Snowstorm. City completely closed. Two days notice. I called on WED for FRI cancel. When I called to re-book they said "WE are a small hotel", and denied any credit. Woulnt even give me buck off as a credit. THEN ... I found their prices were actually higher than The Days Inn on 94th, next to where I needed to go. Skip this budget hotel and their lies; and stay at the Days INN. Cheaper and a big upgrade.

I stayed there 1 week in august 2011.Nothing to complain about, rooms was clean and very big (i don't know why but they gave us the invalid people room) with wood on the floor and not the stupid moquette.Very clean and spacious.I definitely will come back if I return in Ny!Metro at 5 minutes walk.A lot of restaurants nearby.A starbucks 1 minute from the hotel :) perfect for breakfast!
user_location: City of San Marino, San Marino
user_name:
-Cal-
City of San Marino, San Marino

review_body: The stay in the belnord hotel was very good an comfortable.The hotel is very central, two station from the times square. The rooms are little but very clean. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Any times again!

the room-hotel was a little small and noisy due to the proximity to' the lift.very clean but unfriendly staff at the reception. the hotel and 'very well connected with the main stops of metro.linea red, blue and orange

Very convenient location for the subway downtown. Shops locally and close to Central Park, easy walk to theMet.Staff friendly and helpful. Bed comfortable. Heating system good.Our room had only one bedside table which was very inconvenient - our onlly criticism.

I had to stop in New York for two unplanned nights and did not have many options as many hotels were booked. I booked this less than a week in advance. The rooms are tiiiiiiinyyyyyyy, literally no space to move. We had to move the bed right up to the wall so we could find space for our luggage and space to move around. The rooms are not fancy either, but very clean. The walls are thin and we could hear people moving outside. After New York we went to San Francisco, Los Angeles and Las Vegas and this room was by far the poorest yet the most expensive. New York rates are catastrophic. Don't spend much on the room and enjoy the day out in this wonderful city.The receptionist is extremely rude and unfriendly.The location was very convenient though. It was a couple of mins away from the subway station and just a couple of streets away from Central Park. It was lovely to wake up in the morning and take a walk in Central Park then hop onto the subway to go sightseeing or go straight to the airport. It was a short ride away from Times Square.

I always read Tripadvisor reviews before I book a hotel so I was warned that the rooms were small, but I hadn't quite pictured lilliputian. The bed is the smallest Queen I have seen with room for only one bedside table. The 'wardrobe' area is a small rack sticking out of the wall under the TV and the bathroom was a shower (OK), and a toilet overlapped by a basin making sitting a challenging experience. I'd like to say it was all worth it because it was clean - but the sheets weren't that clean - I expect crisp white sheets; these were old and yellowed. And the view? Haha...we were so close to the building next door I could have passed our neighbours a cup of morning tea (if it was available in the hotel which it wasn't), and the proximity meant we couldn't tell if it was sunny, dull, raining. On the plus side...the WiFi is free (although codes changed daily); the location is pretty good - lots of good restaurants within walking distance.Not worth the 'cheap' price. Save up and get a decent hotel.

In short, a condensed experience! Bathroom was brand new, clean and well lighted -- just tiny. The room and hallways were relatively quiet, though spaces are narrow -- I can imagine someone who is claustrophobic might not enjoy their stay. Staff were friendly and efficient, and safe neighborhood, with nearest subway one block south on Broadway, offering convenient transportation and shopping.

The room, if you want to call it that. My closet is larger. There were no bureau's. Could not fit one in the rm. The quilt was really worn. I have thrown out better. It was a very challenging experience. You did not even have rm to roll a suitcase. The tub was a foot bath size. The price was way to expensive for a night. I have stayed in the city at other hotels that were considered economical and received a lot more for your money. Not at the Belnord. The only thing on the positive side was that the mini stamp rm was clean.
user_name:
candyminusc
New York City, New York

review_body: Overall a good location, very close to line 1 subway station. Been there in 2007 and found it completely renewed. However, the bed was not so comfortable, wireless connection didn't work at all and the heating system was terribly noisy. Moreover the personnel was not so kind. A little expensive, too...
Fantastic location, average service, quality of sleep very low due to sound insulation problems. Probably will not stay again.

Due to Hurricane Sandy we had an extra night in NYC. We stayed at the Belnord. We were on the third floor and it was noisy. We could hear the lift every time it stopped. Plus the stairway door was noisy. The passage way was noisy as it was not carpeted and one could hear people coming and going at all hours. Wifi was intermittent. Room was incredibly small, with almost no room on either side of the bed. Bathroom was a fair size. Hotel was very clean. Front desk staff were at best disinterested, however, they were very helpful when trying to book a limo to take us to JFK. The location is very good with plenty of restaurants and cafes close by.
user_name:
downunder2207
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: I've stayed at high-end hotels, I've stayed at budget hotels. On the plus side, this one is clean and in a great residential NYC neighborhood. I knew the rooms would be small -- that I didn't mind -- but I don't know why the halls are so noisy with through traffic. You constantly hear the rolling of luggage. In the morning, I heard someone knock hard on several doors, sort of like housekeeping at some hotels but they knocked particularly loudly and did not say "housekeeping" -- I don't know if this was an anomaly or what. The heater is the room was loud. If you sleep like a rock through anything, well maybe this is OK.

I was visiting my son on the Upper West Side so I wanted a Hotel near him to cut down of the commute. This is a great location in a nice area if you need to be in upper westside. Would be excellent for someone visiting children at Columbia etc. There are a couple of Subways near by, right next to the 1 train. The room was very small, and I had a bigger room after looking in another room with a Double Bed. No dresser, coffee machine, mini bar, bad to nonexistent WiFi. The room did have a closet and small small bathroom. All rooms have no carpets, fake wood floors and tile bathrooms. All was very clean. Nice towels, but bad shampoo and soap. Overall not too bad if yoiu get a good rate. I paid approximately $250 per night with tax.

We came down to see a show and I shopped around quite a bit since, with hotel and transportation and meals out, this quickly becomes an $800 day. This place looked cool, but were we ever surprised by the maze of hallways and then the tiny postage stamp room. Picture a 2.5 foot clearance around the bed -- and that's it, folks. A closet the size of a broom closet, the tiniest bathtub I've ever seen. Other reviews mention bedding, the bed was comfortable but bedding clearly needs updating. The shower was great and the towels plush but that's the best part of it. We went from hot to cold all night and our view was a brick wall. We joked about "room service" and our wonderful coffee maker in the room (not). Even now I can hear my husband in the shower laughing at the size of that bathroom. NYC is expensive, I'll grant you that, but next time I'll gladly cough up another hundred bucks so I don't have to park my luggage on the floor. Total furniture = two bed stands and the bed. No more than 80 square feet. Nice neighborhood, unfriendly staff.

This hotel was clean and up-to-date. Rooms were tiny, tiny - the size of a small closet, I had to close the closet door to open the bathroom door, and could not walk around the bed whe any doors were open (but I guess that's normal in NYC). However, I felt like I was part of a herd of cattle being processed through - no personal attention, no real smile and greeting! I was there on the weekend right after the 2012 storm Sandy. I called to find out about the cancellation policy. The reservation I signed up for said I had to cancel about 48 hours ahead. I thought this might be a special circumstance (the other hotel I was scheduled to stay at said I could cancel up to the day of check in if my flights were cancelled). Anyway, I had no way of knowing whether my flight would be going (could have cancelled more than 24 hours ahead if they'd allowed), but they told me I'd be charged for one night ($272.00 which is really expensive for me to pay for one night to begin with) if I cancelled on Nov.1 (for my Nov. 2 reservation). It seemed to me they might have appreciated some cancellations so that they could help out local NYC residents who were displaced by the storm. Instead, they made me feel compelled to make the trip rather than lose my money! They also had no place to lock anything up for my and no safe in the room. They did not allow any fluctuation in check-in, check-out time. And, although no one was rude to me, they were just rather curt and unapproachable.

Hello Brian W, I'm not sure what you expected, but we were pleasantly surprised by this hotel!!!! Do not listen to this man!! Although the room was small, we were on vacation and only spent about 8 hrs out of 24 in the room anyway! Everything was clean, bed was very comfortable, and staff at the front desk were more than helpful. A very special THANK YOU to Nick who gave my daughter a bandaid from his own backback when he couldn't find one at the desk. If I ever have the chance to visit NYC again, I will be staying here.

its not the hotel I choose when I booked to visit new york, the hotel carter cancelled on me when I was already on my vacation in chicago, i was offered this and we were glad we accepted ,the rooms are very compact but look recently refurbished, claen tidy and modern as we were only there for two nights it was in a good location and we easily walked to it from time square, surrounded by cafes and bars and close too central park. would stop there again

I live in NYC and due to the hurricane had to evacute. The BELNORD was my only option at that point. It was 200 + dollars for the night. The room was a SHOEBOX. My closet is bigger then the room. They Have Creepy old quilt conforters on the beds, with two pillows made out of felt and possibly straw. Did i mention it was small? the door hits the bed when you enter the room. When you lay in the bed you could feel that there was plastic cover the mattress under the pitted sheets. This was a low end HOSTEL. I would not recomend it to my worst enemy. It would be one thing if it were 50 bucks a night, but this place is overpriced and a disgrace to NYC. ANy review below that gives this place any positvie rating is cleary a ploy by the management.
user_name:
brian w
New York City, New York

review_body: We were really happy with this hotel! The location was wonderful - great neighborhood, and close to the subway. The room was very nice and clean, although small. But the size was perfect for just two of us, and considering we were out seeing the city all day and spent very little time in the room, it was perfect. We would recommend this hotel to friends, and we'll stay here again when we visit NYC the next time!

I am a mature solo traveller. I booked an executive double on the fourth floor room - 426. I always request a room away from the vending and ice machines and the elevators. This was a quiet location with a typical NYC view - your neighbors fire escape. The room was exceptionally clean and large enough for two people, had a closet, two bedside tables, a desk and chair, a luggage rack, room for a couple of suitcases, two large windows, and a very very small bathroom. There were outlets next to the bed and under the desk for charging cells and computers. The bathroom had a wall hair dryer, shampoo, soaps, and plastic cups - unfortunately the cups were never replaced in the three days I stayed there. There were no hooks in the bathroom which made it impossible to hang a robe or pjs. The towels were soft and large. There is a fan in the bathroom. Good shower - tall shower head. In room heating/AC digital electronics worked great. Love the carpet-less floors except late at night and early in the morning when the hall traffic is LOUD. The lobby looks like a European boutique hotel and the desk staff was cordial. There is a small coffee machine behind the front desk ($0.50) and a workstation. The location is one short block from the #1 subway line on Broadway which is across the street from a small market and two banks and loads of fantastic shopping. This is a terrific location for visiting Barnard and Columbia. Note: you will have to carry your luggage up several steps to the front door; if you are a heavy packer, you might find the room size frustrating. I paid $247 per night which was the best deal for the time I booked on the upper west side.

The reason we picked this hotel was the location. Nice to get to a not so stressful area after experiencing Manhattan every day. Very close to Central Park. Our room was very close to the elevator and we experienced quite a lot of noise in the early mornings - 4.30-6. Also from the cleaning staff and once from the police. We were told we were lucky to get a room for physically handicapped because of the size of it, we saw an "ordinary" room - wonder where the guests in that room should leave their clothes and trunks. No room at all! The internetconnection isnt very great, not always working, and even though its free, you need a new password every day, very annoying to lose connection, when you are in the middle of a very long email! We had to ask for toiletpaper almost every day, things I,d take for obvious. But the staff is friendly and nice and want to help when you ask them.

it was my second time visiting belnord hotel, the first time i really enjoy it,the second time not so much.i have to say that the hotel is very good, clean and the upper west side is lovely for a stay in NY.the BAD THINGS - -staff really rude, not willing to help at all.-wifi password changes every day, u have to call the front desk every morning.- the phone in the room didnt work , u cant call, buy people from outside can reach u.

So I attempted on many occasions to contact a few individuals who have their personal or rental units featured on Tripadvisor. The problem, and this was a first.... I did not hear back from one of the contacts. This took place over 4 weeks, and well in advance of my jaunt to NY. So in a last minute effort to find accommodations, I started looking at boutique hotels. WHAT A GEM I found - Hotel Belnord was perfection.Ok, so the room was wicked small - even by NY standards. It's ironic really - as the American public generally becomes larger, hotel and other rooms are becoming smaller. In any case, I suggest any single traveler prepare themselves for the diminutive room size. They should also prepare for staying in a vibrant UWS neighborhood, with plenty of exceptional restaurants nearby, including Barney Greengrass! Without exception the service, cleanliness, staff and location are well worth the hotel rates.
Good price for a basic but good quality hotel. The front desk was good, easy place to get cab / buses/ subway and good locale restaurants

It was the 2th time I stayed in this hotel and I've found the people there friendly. The service was really excellent. Although the rooms are small, they are nice & clean! The location is very good, close to the metro, close to C.park, many restaurants in the neighbourhood...and beautiful streets with many trees!The only problem was the noice this time, not from the people, but from the ventilation, but we got another room and there we didn't have the problem anymore!I really hope to come back a 3th time!

The room was the smallest I ever seen. We were two people in a "double room" but only one of us could move at a time!They write they have Wi-Fi but the connection is actually really low so we had to move between Starbucks for some internet.They didn't give us a proper blanket until we specifically requested one.although the hotel is in Manhattan it is really close to anything. We regretted staying at this hotel.

No assistance, no help to carry bags. The room is ridiculously tiny, with one double bed and no room for two people to walk around. No place to put your clothes: no dresser, no closet, only a metal bar with two hangers. The bathroom inadequate, too, no place to put anything.  It's one thing to advertise your hotel as 'no frills' if it is value for money. This hotel is in a good neighborhood in NYC and we spent $500 for two nights and received very poor value.I would not recommend this place to anyone.

This is a practical hotel, nothing fancy, but clean and well-located. I've never seen narrower hallways or a smaller room, but the room was clean and had no odor issues. The bed was reasonably comfortable. I could open the window for air. The only negative I can think of is that, with no carpeting in the hallway, noise is an issue. Cleaning staff sounded like they were yelling to each other and banging things. But who really spends time in their room when in NYC? The hotel is located in a great neighborhood, away from the tourist nightmare of Midtown. A nice walk down Broadway or a hop on the adjacent subway will get you wherever you want to go.

Very clean for a moderate priced room. Great location. Very small rooms. It's only a place toto sleep and shower. Very Spartan but functional and convenient. If you must be in NYC andyour not rich, this place will do the job nicely. Management and staff really try hard.

It´s a very small hotel, located from a walking distance of the Central Park and the Museum of Natural History, and it also has a subway station close, that in 15 minutes takes you to Times Square and the main attractions of Manhattan. Around the hotel you can find a Starbucks, a walgreens, that is very useful. It is located in a nice neighborhood, and around the hotel there are some nice restaurants and bars with latin and dominican republic food. It has free wifi, and has two computers that charges US$5.00 per 10 minutes in Internet. The rooms are very small, but clean. The only thing I didn´t like is that we need to take a taxi to the airport, they don´t get yellow cabs, and the cost is US$60.00 and tip (optional). It is like a line of taxis for executives, but when we got to the airport, the driver asked us for US$65.00 and a obligatory amount of tip....So, if you need to go to Manhattan, looking for a room to sleep, this is it...because it´s cheaper than the hotels in Manhattan..The people in the front desk are not very nice, though...

Great location just off Broadway with an underground station one block away. Functional place but really tiny rooms, with even tinier bathrooms and a closet good for a couple of shirts. Expect no views of amenities, but it suffices as a place to sleep.

spent one night last week at this hotel with my gf.the room is tiny and basically just has space for the bed which was comfortable.bathroom is tiny and there is no room for 2 people at the same time.view was a brickwall of the hous next door.however this is nyc and the room is clean and had no complaints. tv has enough channels and i liked that there was a wood floor instead of a dirty carpet.location is great whit it being just one block away from a subway station.

I really think that one should ignore the reviews dating back to 2005 that showed some prices ridiculously low in today's context, and also those of 2009 or 2010 when the Upper West side was plagued by bedbugs in hotels from the highest to the lowest. We stayed there in August/September of 2012, for 8 nights and paid an average of $216 per night including taxes (booked through Expedia). This was a Belnord different to many previous reviews. In fact, most of it looked as if had recently been refurbished. It did have an elevator. It had wooden floors. It had an adequate reception area. The room we were given was small, but not too small, apparently one of the largest they have: not enough space to hang clothes or put them in a wardrobe, so we had to live out of our suitcases. Partitions were made of some sort of plywood so that every word spoken outside was well audible inside. But it had a 26 inch TV set (HD, as all are now in the US) with the Time-Warner set of channels. These do not carry a single foreign language (Spanish can no longer be considered a FOREIGN language in New York, like in many other US locations), so that some of the other guests we spoke to were disappointed. It also was so superclean that we had to abandon all thoughts of how to avoid bedbugs, thoughtfully provided to us by Yahoo Travel. All bedclothes and utilities were changed every day, which led to an experience unheard of in the more than a hundred hotels that I have visited over the years: I put my undercover billfold (flat and plastic) in the pillowcase, as I am used to in my travels. But I forgot it there… In the evening I was sure that I had lost the several hundred dollars of spending money that I had put there. But the next morning the reception clerk to whom appealed called the head of the maids, and when my wife produced its exact twin the lady handed my billfold over. All the money was there, although it had gone to the laundry and made its way back from there washed. Needless to say – we were overjoyed. As for the rest – the Upper West Side is a pleasant and safe part of the city and has many attractive shops. Bus lines and the Underground are a stone's throw away from the hotel. The staff are friendly and helpful. The rate was far lower that that of other hotels in New York, especially since we could not book far in advance. Places to eat are nearby – three in the same bloc. And the other guests, who spoke a Babel of languages, were all quiet-spoken and courteous, meaning there was no noise to complain about at all. Definitely value for money. Three cheers for the Belnord! AmosH Jerusalem

The hotel is very clean with no moquette, but parquet on floor. Restrums are clean and towels are changed every day. It is near Caffe' Lalo a good place to have the breakfast avoiding starbucks and having the possibility to choose between many cakes and a perfect italian capuccino. To reach the hotel you have to use the 1 metro red line stopping at 86. It is near the central park. If I have to write a drawback it is the room dimension. I first had the number 104 (ground floor) with the promise of a change because too small for two, but we waited two days to change the room. The second one was better.

Stayed here recently for 5 nights, it was my first trip to NYC and we were just looking for an affordable base from which to see the city. The hotel is very clean, with good air conditioning but rooms are so tiny, the shower was hot and cold, and front desk staff (bar one guy, who was pleasant) are SO unfriendly. I've never stayed in a hotel where I didnt receive a warm welcome, I also used to work in hotels so I know how important these first impressions are! We used the hotel as a base for our sightseeing, and it served its purpose as that. The room was so small, but we didn't spend much time in it so we were not too bothered by it. The location is good with plenty restaurants/cafes nearby and central park, and natural history museum within walking distance, and a subway station literally round the corner. We didn't have a bad experience, but it could have been better.

Arriving at a hotel, even a budget hotel, l expect a few things...pleasant staff and a nice pest-free room. Didn't get that here. Instead, I got rude staff and a GOD AWEFUL small room with cockroaches!!! Horrible experience that I hope no one else will ever have to go through!

Small and poorly designed room with NO storage. Bed too short for normal size adults, no closet in bedroom, no hooks or towel racks in bathroom, no place to store even a carry on bag. Small would be ok if design were better able to accommodate basic needs or even minimal unpacking.Front desk staff disengaged to the point of rudeness. On the plus side it's very clean and well located.

There was a rat in my room. I told housekeeping AND reception but nothing was done after the second night so I left. To make matters worse, they refused to give my money back for the two nights that I didn't stay there meaning I paid over $400 in accommodation when I was staying somewhere else. Furthermore, the bed could only just fit in the room and the only window faced straight onto another wall so no light could get through. Avoid at all costs.
user_name:
Amelia_91
New York City, New York

review_body: My husband and I travelled to NYC for July 4th to see the stunning Macy's Fireworks. We are "points rewards" credit card holders and this hotel was featured as a points reward hotel on our card for $110.00 per night (and for $150 on priceline for July 5-7). It was extremely clean, close to the subway, and not far from central park with a 24hr convenience store on the corner so for $110 bucks we felt like we won the lottery. Our room was a very clean small room equipped with one bed, a flat screen tv, phone, wireless connection, and a clean bathroom. After long days of sight seeing and shopping that is all that we needed. On the flip side the cable went out during our stay, however, we did receive small compensation for the inconvenience.NYC is an expensive city so don't travel there expecting cheap hotel stays with palatial space, instead most hotels $200/night or cheaper tend to be very disappointing and unsanitary places. The Belnord is clean and you can't beat the location. It is what it is!

This hotel was used for our 4night stay at NY city during our road trip.It's a clean hotel with small rooms.Hotel is located in side street so there is not a lot of noise.If you pick a room with a double bed, the room is almost full.People in the hotel are kindYou have free WIFI You have no good view from the window of the roomBecause it's NY, the price of the hotel more than you are used to.In my opinion, there are better hotels with more value for money!You have a lot of shops to have breakfast and a lot of restaurants in the area

My husband and I were fooled by the pix posted on their website. Rooms were the size of a closet, not to mention the tiny bathroom. My husband and I were getting ready to see the sights, and once my Husband took a shower, the water kept rising and was clogged. We called to the front desk, had to wait 45 minutes for them to send someone up to fix the tub. It was nasty!! The staff was very rude, and would NEVER EVER stay there again!! Next time we will def. stay elsewhere!!!! Even the hallways are small and had a hard time sleeping on the hard bed, with the 1 flat pillow!!
user_name:
Sally B
Ithaca, New York, United States

review_body: We recently visited NYC for 5 days and stayed at the Belnord Hotel on the upper west side. The location cannot be beat as it is close to two metro lines (The 1 and the A&B.) It is also close to Central Park and Riverview Park. The streets that it is near are lined with trees and brownstones. There are many eating places nearby - I can recommend several. The staff was helpful and polite at all times. I asked for another pillow and within minutes it came.The rooms are small as stated by other reviewers, but also very very clean. The walls are rather thin so you can hear doors opening and closing down the hall. They do have a coffee machine that cost 50 cents for a cup of coffee and that was all I needed. I am good with one cup but serious coffee drinkers will probably want to go to Dunkin Donuts as my husband did.The bottom line is this hotel is in a wonderful location, the staff is helpful and polite and the room is clean. Do you go to NYC to sit in your room? If you do - this is not the place for you. If you go to have a great time and need a place that is safe clean and quiet then the Belnord is for you.

Why can't there be more hotels like this in New York City...a budget hotel that is also wonderfully clean and fresh looking, even if the rooms are tiny...I am at the hotel this week and had never stayed here before so was a little worried given the great rate, but it's a real gem as long as you're not claustrophobic..As many others have said, all that most people need in new york is a clean place to sleep, since when we're in town we are out all day and sometimes late at night..This hotel is a lovely, charming old building on a pleasant tree-lined street, just a block to the Subway that goes downtown quickly...I loved the quiet and calm of the neighbourhood compared to midtown...This hotel appears to have been recently renovated, complete with a nice restoration on the brick on the outside of the building...I also liked that it's a small, quiet hotel as opposed to one of those giant places where the lobby is always swarming with hundreds of people coming and going...this is a small hotel, about five storeys, and you rarely see more than 1 or 2 people in the lobby at a time..My room, fine for me since I was alone, was a double bed room, where as others have said, there isnt room for much more than the bed, and the small bathroom, but there are new hardwood floors, fresh wallpaper, flat-screen TV on the wall, and above all, excellent air conditioning...which is the main thing in NY in the summer.My room looked out onto a classic NY maze of fire escapes on a narrow alley, but I was actually glad of this since I didnt have to worry about street traffic noise...I slept wonderfully peacefully..I was on my own and only had a small carry on, but two people with big suitcases might find it more challenging..when you want to unpack something there arent a lot of places to open a suitcase other than on the bed, but it worked...But I have also travelled in Britain and europe and I have seen rooms there that aren't much bigger than this, so as long as you know to expect that, it's OKBest of all, I got a rate of $135 through expedia...I don't think it's possible to find a room in NY for any cheaper than that for this quality and which also has its own bathroom..There are some European-style places that have communal washrooms in the halls where you might get a lower price than that, or real dumps..but for this quality I'd love to know of any that match this at that price...Upper west side is also a nice, quiet, low-key neighbourhood that's fun to explore and I love how quiet it is ...a friend is staying right in Times Square and hates the noise she hears from the hotel every night...and she's paying more than I was at the Belnord...The staff could use a little training on friendliness...the night desk guy barely looked up when I entered the lobby coming home late tonight, but I can live with that for this price...I would definitely stay here again if I could get a similar rate...Dont know if this was a special deal that I got or not...it was what came up when I searched for a room on expedia..Thanks for the great stay, Belnord!

Went to New York on 7/12/2012 Was a very small room I am talking small i bumped my shoulder on the TV on the wall trying to get around the bed. But you could not have asked for a cleaner room and hotel. Pillow were flat Since we only slept there it met our needs. If you are a large person or have a lot of luggage don't stay there.

I stayed 4 nights during July 2012. This hotel is probably the cleanest hotel I have ever stayed at. It is super super clean. The room was very small as many have pointed out, but my husband and I did not mind, since we are small and thin, and we only used the hotel to sleep. I would not recommend this hotel for large people, unless you are a solo traveler in which case you will have the room for yourself. Other highlights for this hotel are the proximity to subway station and to great restaurants. I would definitely stay in this hotel again if price is right, I paid approx 145 per night, inclusive of taxes and fees. Anything over that is unwarranted. Also, there is a coffee machine right behind the front desk. Coffee is .50 cents.

Primary concern staying in NYC was that the hotel should be clean and bug free - this one was. It was spotlessly clean and nicely air-conditioned. Staff were quick to respond to any problems and the hotel is only one block from the red 1 line and 2 avenues over from the blue and orange line. We found it a handy base for seeing New York. Downsides were that the room was TINY. When we looked at the fire escape plan beside the lift it did seem like we literally got the smallest room on the floor - there was barely enough space to walk around the bed, none if you decided to put your luggage down, so it did require extreme tidyness or you'd be tripping over yourself. That said, it was fully formed in that it had a double bed, 2 bedside lockers, En Suite, TV and a small wardrobe in it.Overall a good experience that I would recommend. Think it cost us about €140 a night on average. One thing I will say is that there should have been a guest information packet in the room. A bit odd that there wasn't!

This former welfare hotel has been beautifully remodelled and was exactly where we needed to stay. However our tiny twin room was right next to the elevator, which is thoughtlessly equipped with both an inside and outside bell when floors are reached.Quite noisy. As well, there was no closet or even a wall hook- we ended up laying our clothes across a desk. The staff refused to move us to the twin room next door, which was further from the elevator and did have a closet. Wifi was almost always impossible to access, and one was not permitted to dial an outside line on the room telephones. Quite frustrating in all, as pretty and new as the decor is.

I loved the Belnord Hotel. When i started planning my trip, i wanted to make sure that the hotel was very very clean! When we arrived at Belnord, i even checked the sheets, the mattress and even under the bed and it was so clean! Yes the room are small but i was only there to visit NY and not to stay in my room so it didnt bother. Very good i highly recommend this hotel!

The room was the tiniest room I have ever been in. No room for anything but a double bed and we paid almost $300.00 per night due to Columbia Univ. graduation. We had no choice. What a ripoff. I would have given it one star but the rooms were very clean.A horrible experience .

I got a queen bed room and it was clean, smell fresh. I think it is the only positive reason I had for this hotel. Don't trust the pictures you see from the website. The actual room is very small that it could fit only the bed. So does its bathroom. Just a l one leap from the end of the bed, you will get into the tiny little bathroom. In the shower area, you will have to turn around yourself to be able to wash every parts of your body because the water pour down slow. Anyway, it might take you a very hard time to turn yourself in that small little area. I am 5"2 and weigh a 105 pound. Rethink about staying in this hotel if you are consider a big person. I paid about 200 dollars per night and I got what I paid for the high season in NYC. However, compare to the Club Quarter , the hotel I stayed before and paid at the same price range, Belnord hotel is worse. The hotel is very close to subway, starbucks, Bank of America, 24 hours food and pastry shop, CVS, DuanReade.

HORIBLE,The pictures on the internet is not representing the hotel running by some Indian people which are so rude unhelpfull1- no telephone in the rooms 2- rooms are smaller than you can imagine I had to switch to a handy cap room so i would get some extra space, the internet had problem they did not help me at all and they didn't have any technician, no amenities NOTHING!!!! for one extra night they double charched me even the Expedi agent was shocked
user_location: White Plains, New York, United States
user_name:
Ali S
White Plains, New York, United States

review_body: Belnord hotel was superb value for money, you are staying in a very nice area of Manhattan with loads of restaurants bakeries and grocery shops nearby. If I was to stay in Manhattan again I would certainly choose this hotel. The staff were very helpful and friendly, you were near a subway station, very close to central park and all in all it was a excellent hotel.

As said by others the rooms are small so be warned. Cleanliness and air con is excellent. However, the staff could be more helpful. There is a luggage room which was useful for us to use after we checked out on our last day. It was a good thing we thought to ask. Then we found that there was a coffee machine and computers which we didn't know about during our stay...........

The Belnord is a great little hotel, and I do mean little. The hallways are very narrow, the rooms are just big enough to hold a double bed, and the bathrooms... well, the bathrooms have a door, but I'm not sure why because you can't close it if you are standing in the bathroom. On the other hand, every thing is incredibly clean, the beds are comfy, and the air-conditioning is the best I've found in the City. This last is very important if you want to survive 35C (95F) and 90% humidity. The subway is only half a block away so the whole city is easily accessible and central park is just a few block up 87th. Great hotel at a great location.

Stopped here for 4 nights last week. Lovely Hotel nice area and Subway just across the road on Broadway. Handy for all the all the attractions and plenty of restaurants to eat. The only downfall was the wifi sometimes it worked but the signal was very weak and kept cutting out had to use Mc Donalds to get a better reception.Thank god for the Air Con needed it as it was very hot

Was a little dubious when booking having read other reviews, but was more than pleased on arrival; the rooms are enormous, but you don't go to NYC to stay in your hotel rooms. They are however spotlessly clean, with a good bathroom and excellent AC (appreciated when NY's having a heatwave!). Being fairly self-sufficient we didn't have need to tax reception too much. Only annoyance was the intermittentness of the wifi, guys please look into improving this. Position is excellent, only a couple minutes walk to 86th St subway on line 1 and the neighbourhood is nice with good places to eat and drink. All in all, an excellent base if you don't want the hustle, bustle and expense of staying Midtown.
user_location: The Royal Town of Sutton Coldfield, United Kingdom
user_name:
Witherspoon68
The Royal Town of Sutton Coldfield, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed here for 7 nights in late November 2011. I am new to Trip Advisor hence my late review. Having read the reviews I was a little apprehensive about staying. I travelled from the UK on my own so I wanted everything to run smoothly. Check in was very easy. I was in my room within minutes.I found my room to be small but for me it was fine. I had enough room to put my suitcase on the floor and still walk around. There was a desk for my laptop and a decent sized flat screen tv. The room was spotless and so was the bathroom, which had a modern decor. The bed in the room was also comfortable. As I was in NYC I hardly spent any time in my room, there is no need to in a city like this. There were no amenities at the hotel (that i was aware off) but the hotel served it's purpose. The staff were helpful and most of them were friendly. As I said i was only there to sleep so i didn't really deal with the staff much. The hotel is in an amazing location. I wanted to stay on the Upper West Side to get away from the hustle and noise of the city. It was quiet and peaceful and was in easy access to many great bars and restaurants. I spent hours walking around this neighbourhood. From what I seen the subway / underground was only around the corner but I am a walker so i went everywhere on foot. I would stay here again providing I got a good deal on rates. It wasn't until after I booked the hotel that I noticed better hotels with similar rates.

having read others' reviews, there were no surprises. WYSIWYG! Renovated, clean, tiny rooms, good location. Only extra comment: wifi hardly ever works, so-called tech. support unable to sort problems. Receptionist's recommendation for garage costs double of what's available on the web. Otherwise satisfied. I would pick Kefi for a good reasonable meal, and nearby Joe's for a good coffee, on Amsterdam Ave.
user_name:
Tomi K
North West England, United Kingdom

review_body: Like everyone has said- the rooms are tiny but perfect for what we needed- a place to leave our things and sleep. Room had beautiful hardwood floors and was immaculate. Area around hotel is very nice and quiet with great restaurants and bars- try Celeste for inexpensive italian food and jacob's pickles for drinks. Would certainly stay again.

very impolite people , all lies on internet , no one will help you if you get in to trouble no phone in the rooms beside calling the desck even the local phone is not possible No Jim No pool rooms are so amall that feet only a full (not king bed) and one feet around it no desck they double vharged me for one extra night no american receptionist!!! LIERS LIERS, I called expedia and they were shucked for what they did to me and unfortunatly I had No time to change this trible place.

My family or 4 (5yo twins) stayed there in January for 3 days. It has been renovated and the family room on the ground floor was especially good and worth asking for - a fairly long room so the twins could sleep one end and we (parents) the other and watch TV after they went to sleep. Front desk was helpful. Fairly quiet side street with short walk to subway, cafes etc. Would recommend to families on a budget who want reasonable comfort and good location.

I just spent two nights at Belnord and agree with one commenter who pointed out the importance of adjusting expectations. Yes, the rooms are tiny; yes, the amenities are limited, but it's not a hostel, it's not the YMCA or camping or bunking on somebody's couch. It's a safe, immaculately clean, reasonably modern and superbly located hotel. For the money, I consider it a prize. The staff varied from very friendly (particularly a young man named Daniel) to unsmiling, but civil. And no wonder the facilities are spotless. House-cleaning staff seemed to be everywhere, dusting and polishing surfaces to a high gleam. Here are the specific issues that I would love to see Belnord management address: 1. Make it easier for guests to get luggage up the front steps. 2. Reward staff that excels in friendly customer service with bonuses so that everyone else will follow suit. 3. Update the media room so that guests can either use the printer free of charge or streamline the entire process. I tried to print my boarding passes and encountered all sorts of problems with the hotel's pay-by-the-minute system. The culprit was slow computer speed that ate up my prepaid minutes before I could print. The front-desk man offered to put in for reimbursement, but it sounded like a hassle, so I followed his recommendation and went up Broadway a few blocks to a copier store. This was my unhappiest moment at Belnord. Everything else was peachy keen--for the money.

Of course, it is not the most expensive hotel in NYC so you cannot expect the best service. Nevertheless, when the fire alarm is ringing at 3am for no reason, you can expect some explanations (especially when you call guest services) and apologies, but we got neither of them. Consequently, the overall quality of service in this hotel is quite poor. That is why I strongly advise you to not sleep in this hotel.

My stay at this hotel was horrible. The hotel staff provides poor customer service, pretends to speak little english and very unfriendly. The rooms are extremely small with very little space to move around. The management cares solely about the business than the needs of the guests.

Hotels in New York are expensive, so do not take European hotel price standards to measure against! And do remember that fees and taxes come extra!Belnord Hotel is perfectly situated in Upper West side, very convenient to the subway (several lines), to the Central park and to lots of food in Broadway and Amsterdam avenues. The rooms are VEEERRRY small, but scrupulously clean (change of towels every day). It is also fairly quiet. The reception people will address you issues (I had something broken in the bathroom and that was immediately attended to), but do not expect more than that (they do not know much). They have free WLAN, which I cid not use, but still find convenient.

while most reviews spoke to the smallness of the rooms, we were drawn to the location away from the madding crowd of midtown and only 1 block from the 1,2,3 subway line for easy commute down or uptown. A quick walk to Central Park and perfectly situated between Broadway and Amsterdam which offered nice selection of restaurants and bars.And the best feature of the Hotel is the CLEANLINESS!!! Staff was helpful, too! I will definitely stay here again....

Stayed at Belnord Hotel for two nights, the rooms are extremely small, maybe two feet from the sides of the beds to the walls, but this worked for our needs. A clean place to sleep with great access to the subway and close to central park. The size of the room encourages you not to spend time in the room, but instead go out and enjoy the city. Would happily stay here again, it may not be 5 star luxury, but it fit all of our needs.

The room was very small, hardly room to walk around the bed. The room and bathroom were very clean, and there was hot running water. The heater in the room worked, as did the AC. The location is safe, I didn't feel uncomfortable walking around at 2am. It wasn't very far from all the sights. Subway stops were close by, also a good deal of restaurants. All in all a very good experience.
user_name:
Rebecca C
Jacksonville, Florida, United States

review_body: Other reviews mention that the rooms are small; it's hard to get an appreciation for just how small they are until you see them. The bedroom was about 6' x 8', or just slightly larger than a double bed. As long as that is what you're expecting, then you'll be prepared to enjoy your stay.The service was good, if not overly helpful. The room was clean and appeared to have been recently renovated. There was a small LCD TV mounted on the wall (as there was no other place to put it!). The bathroom was clean and the shower water pressure was surprisingly strong for the third floor. The location is outstanding, with short walks to some good eating, the subway, and both Riverside and Central Parks. I would stay there again.

My internship buddy and I had to stay here for the first four nights as our hostel wasn’t ready then. Location-wise, it’s perfect because the neighborhood is safe and the hotel is located in the central area within the Upper West Side neighborhood. Busses and subways are readily near. The hotel lobby is small but cozy with a receptionist handling all our booking and other requests.Our check-in was fuzz-free. All it took was the receptionist getting our information and handling us the key and within minutes, we were dragging our luggage up to our room. There weren’t bellboys to aid us with our luggage but that was fine, as our rooms were very near the lift so it wasn’t an issue.Upon entering, I was a little taken aback by the size of the room. It was tiny, with three quarter of the room being taken up by the two single beds. However, it was very clean. Basic amenities such as clean towels, clean bedding, proper working shower system and toilet bowl, hairdryer, shampoo and soap, clean rolls of toilet papers and a working television were available. In fact, all these were more than enough for a night’s stay. There was even a dressing table and a huge mirror. The toilet was pretty big considering the size of the room. No bathtub, but a good and working standing shower and most of all the toilet was clean and reek-free!I highly recommend budget-travelers to consider the Belnord Hotel if you’re looking for accommodation in Manhattan or the Upper West Side because the surrounding is very safe and quiet as it's mainly residential areas. There are also plenty of fast food locations, convenient stores and casual eateries all around which are really good since the hotel itself doesn’t provide dining services.
We chose, and paid for, one of the larger rooms. Good location; and good accommodation by New York standards.

Price and location wise, is a great option.rooms are tiny but clean.the main problem is the lack of service. you can be in the hotel many days and the staff wont look or interact with you.there is no commitment with service.breakfast is ordinary to bad, but for the price you can´t expect more.i have stayed in better places with a much more convenient rate.it would be, as it was, my final option if anything else is available.

The room was very small...however this was our first trip to new York...and maybe the small hotels are like this. The hotel staff was amazing. Helpful and friendly. Everything was very very clean. This is the most important part of any trip for me!

The rooms were tiny, but we expected that based on prior reviews and it was not an issue. For the first half of the trip, we stayed in town (next to Grand Central) and I preferred this West End location. A few blocks from Central Park, one block from subway which went directly to Times Square and then Chelsea, loads of restaurants/bars within walking, car rental locations were just 3 blocks away, and more of a neighborhood feel than strictly tourists. We arrived mid morning with luggage and were able to store our bags in a secured room until checkin time. It is not fancy - no bellhop, no coffee on site, walls are thin enough so it would be hard to sleep in if you wanted as the hallway noise ramps up in the mornings. But, nice size LED tv, helpful staff, clean room, free wifi, reasonable cost made this a good choice if you are the active sort and don't plan to spend a lot of time in the room.

The rooms are tiny but all we need in NYC. My husband and I only brought in one suitcase because we knew the space limitations. The room is only large enough for the full size bed and a nightstand. The suitcase served as our computer stand - wi-fi was on and off but we could deal with that. They also have computers on the first floor and there's a minimal charge. Coffee is available from a machine on the first floor (50 cents) but several delis are right around the corner on Broadway. The parking lot is on the next street and costs $35.00 per night. We did not drive anywhere. It's an easy walk to Central Park. Broadway has with many choices for restaurants and shops. We ate at "Hot and Crusty" and at "City Diner" which are both very close. The subway stop is not very far; we took that to lower Manhattan for the day.

Those were the most important factors to me as I was traveling with my teenage daughter; I wanted to be in a safe area and building and no issues with cleanliness. It is in a good area and right near the subway. It is about 30 blocks, or a 40-min. walk to Columbia University. The room was tiny, as I had expected after reading other reviews, but that was OK as we didn't spend much time there. As some others mentioned, you do hear noise from the hall, I assume because of the vinyl floors. So even though the other guests were quiet, I could still hear footsteps, doors shutting (loud) and wheeled luggage going down the hall. We probably heard more of that than other guests since our room shared one wall with the elevator. Surprisingly, the elevator wasn't noisy, but we did hear the "ding" whenever it stopped on our floor. The bathroom was fine, clean and roomy enough to do hair and makeup. The TV worked fine, we only watched it a little. The wireless was fine but I barely used it. We paid about $220/night including taxes & fees for a Friday & Saturday stay. I didn't have any issues with the staff on check-in or check-out, there were no problems with my reservation.

Incredibly noisey at all hours and their 'double rooms' only have three quarter beds in them. You can touch all 4 walls at once the rooms are so small. Staff were friendly enough though and it on a corner to a subway stop.

the rooms and bathroom are small but fine if u want no frills. its quite a bit out the way of main attractions but subways around the corner although i found them confusing. there is a starbucks, papajohns, dunkin donuts. and subway shops around the corner for snacks and coffee. the lift is a bit annoying as r room was right next to it and you could hear it double beeping throughout the night and morning.

i stayed 4 nights in this hotel . it was really nice. the bedroom is small.you can share a bed only if you are two skinny girls. and that was our case.if you are two big people book 2 beds or 1 king size.the room was small, but really cute, i only have 2 carry on. so i was ok.the room has no views at all. the staff speak Spanish, they charge u for using the computers. u can use the phone of the common area but u cant use the phone from your room.the area is great to get far away for the craziness of new york for a little while. is close to everything. but is a lovely quite neighborhood witch i loved. the subway is close and the central park is right away.

The hotel is situated in a very quiet area and the rooms are small but SPOTLESS CLEAN. Right near the subway entry and a few steps from Central Park.On the east wing of the hotel there is some machine that starts and stops and makes the room vibrate when on. The west wing seemed very quiet. The apartment from the adjacent building had a A/C unit mounted in the window that came very close to our window, but it was spring and they never started it. We also did not start the fan nor CAC. After check-out you can leave your luggage in an unattended basement room at your own risk as per the notes posted and although you enter with a one-time-use-card and there never has been a problem, it feels uneasy as the room has no surveillance camera.I would recommend this hotel as for this price it is better and less noisy than others.

The location (upper west side) and value (around $250/night) are good for Manhattan. The Belnord Hotel is located within walking distance from Central Park and Columbia University. It is a short cab ride (20 blocks) from Times Square. My friend and I were given a handicap accessible room which we did not request but we did appreciate. It was large enough for the both of us and the bathroom was large. The bathroom amenities are average. There is no iron in the room.On the other hand, the customer service at this hotel is the worst I've ever experienced. First of all, not one of the 4 employees I encountered during my 5 day stay had a grasp of the English language. Unless you speak Spanish, which I do, you will have a hard time communicating, especially with housekeeping. I was meeting a friend in NYC and she was flying in internationally. I called the hotel to leave her a message advising of my flight delay. A message was taken begrudgingly by Jonathan. When I called a second time to inform of a further flight delay, Jonathan yelled, "I already gave your friend the message!" Come to find out, he relayed my message to my friend only when she walked up and asked if she could check in (the reservation was in my name.) He told her she could not check in because the reservation was not in her name but when she insisted he allowed her to check in. The fact that security or compliance are not main concerns at this hotel is worrisome but nothing unusual happened during our stay. I never checked into the hotel. My friend was able to obtain 2 room keys and I paid for my portion of our stay without ever having to give my name or formally check in. Housekeeping starts early at this hotel so if you are not an early riser, place the Do Not Disturb sign on the doorknob. Free Wi-Fi is offered. You must obtain a code from the front desk each day that you wish to use it. I was only able to use it for 30 minutes during my 5 day stay. When I called the front desk they told me to call tech support who was very helpful and polite but it seemed the issue was with the connection at the hotel which tech support could not resolve. The phones in the room are to call the front desk ONLY! Be mindful of this if you will not have a cell phone during your stay.My friend and I limited our interaction with the hotel staff and had a pleasant stay. I would recommend this hotel for its value if you can look past customer service.

I got a pretty good deal of 129 a night, so it was adequate. The room was small but very clean, the reception area also small but nice, a little retro-chic that's probably original. Front desk personnel very helpful and the internet was free, very nice. Great neighborhood for eating, shopping, subway access, close to the park. When I checked again for staying a week later on a return trip the price was double, in which case it would not be anywhere near a decent value. So, check it out and don't be afraid to choose this place if the price is decent.They did have some sort of off-putting signs something to the effect of if you are one minute past the noon check-out they'll have you thrown in debtor's prison, but I was leaving early so it didn't become an issue. Still, not a very welcoming attitude, that.

Sincerely when I booked the hotel and start reading the reviews I think the worst. But when i open the door of the room it was small, but for two it is perfect.The room and bathroom was super clean. The sheets and towels were changed every day. The train station is at one street walking. Also they have a vending machine and ice machine at the basement. While employees were friendly and kind. They provide a place to leave your luggage after check out with out a cost. They also coordinate the transportation to the airport. For my and my wife was perfect. If you want some photos email to me jsantiago05@gmail.com

Small clean rooms, helpful staff in reception, excellent wifi. Easy to reach and start exploring NY by subway. Nice breakfast places close, at Amsterdam Avenue. Thanks and see You again, already sent You other guests :-) !

the room service is only service available and poor, watch your belongings when you go out. there is no phone even if you want to pay so if you don't have a cell do not go there, the web rate was 120 and one extra night they made me pay 250 and when I wanted to go to another hotel they said it's 12:05 you have to pay 75 dollar as soon as I wanted to get ready it become 1:03 and it become ONE FULL DAY now I had no way!!! I had problem with their internet and they gave me such a hard time. this hotel seems to be in the hand of some private Indian firm not a legitimate american or European this people are horrible so rude so unhelpful I hated my stay at this hotel.
user_location: White Plains, New York, United States
user_name:
Ali S
White Plains, New York, United States

review_body: The hotel is in a great quiet location (Upper West Side, Manhattan). It is a 3 min walk to the subway (86th Street) and about a 10 minute walk to Central Park. The area is filled with some great cafes, breakfast diners and restaurants. If you feel adventurous you can walk to Times Square, which took us approximately 45 minutes.Everything you hear about the rooms is true. They were the smallest rooms I have ever seen and they include a bed, two small side tables and very little walking space. If you are sharing the room with someone, it will feel like a crammed obstacle course as you are constantly jumping over bags and your luggage. The washroom is also very small. Overall the place is clean, the staff was polite and approachable and the price was reasonable for the location (we got a great deal online). If you need a lot of space in your hotel room, this is not the place for you. If you don’t spend much time in your room since you are exploring this amazing city, then this hotel is a decent option. FYI - parking is half a block away and will cost you $35 a night (hotel discount rate).

Our first visit to the city and we were thrilled to find such a great place to stay. It was so incredibly convenient to the subway, great places to eat in the area, and our room was always extremel clean. The room was small but we felt very cozy and we really didn't spend much time in our room at all. We stayed out late every night and slept in every morning until 9 or 10am and it was always nice and quiet. We always felt safe walking back to the hotel after a late night out. We definitely would stay here again.

This hotel is in a great location, quiet street, near lots of restaurants, and very close to the subway. It has been renovated recently, and the rooms are exceptionally clean. The only down side is the size of the rooms. The double room is so small, only one double bed and one nightstand fit. It would be fine for a single person, but it is cramped with 2 people.
Everything was ok! Clean room and cleam bathroom.No bad things to say about the hotel and the staff !!

The room was way over priced for the area and the rooms where incredibly small. They do not have conditioner. Also there is some type of machine that makes the room vibrate. I have been in new York for a little of a week and only one night was spent here. For the price of one night here I could stay in time square for two nights. Big disappoint!!

Stayed at belnord in December 2011. Me and my boyfriend we stayed here for four nights.I must say that the rooms are small but they are modern and clean. Flat screen t.v and clean towels.I would stay here again and recommend this stay.it's really affordable and staff was help full.

1) clean room & bathroom2) considered spacious for a NY hotel especially Upper West Side area3) DO NOT stay if you need to sleep in. I can't sleep past 8pm because the cleaning crew was talking extra loud to each other, and making so much noise banging their equipment, closing doors, and it happened every day. 4) And even though they clean the bathroom, they never scrub the tub, so at the end of our stay the tub becomes extremely slippery. 5) If you need reception to call a cab for you, make sure you mention yellow cab, because they called an expensive town car for us, so they can get commission.
user_name:
Tres Chic B
Kirkland, Washington, United States
